Overall, it was a good enough meal accompanied by friendly service. But next time I'm in North Beach,  I think I'll go around the corner and have pasta at Ideale.   Ciao!
author: Diane J.

description: I don't like Italian food, but Caffe Sport is one of my favorite places for Italian food when I have to eat Italian.  Their prawn appetizer with white sauce is to die for.  Suggestion to make it better is to accept credit cards.  Bring lots of cash, especially you like to drink and eat a lot as it is a cash only establishment.
author: Kmaintl L.

description: Enjoyed it all but the salad. Ha!  The Cioppino is a variety of sea creatures mixed up and sauced enough to make you want to use your hands!  And of course, that's OK!  Hint: Bring home as much of the orange bread dip as you can for a tastey discovery found in my next review of Chili's.
author: Michael B.

description: If you want some good family style Italian off the beaten path that is Colmubus and Broadway, you should definitely come here. This place is cute, quaint, and cozy. You always start off your meal with bread and dipping sauce...yum! Their seafood stew is to die for...and you can never go wrong with their fried calamari. Overall, and awesome place. BE SURE TO BRING CASH AS THEY DON'T ACCEPT ATM. Luckily, there's a Bank of America ATM down the street.
author: Grace L.

description: Cool spot for the group.  Has very interesting decoration and the portion of the food is reasonable.  They serve mostly Italian seafood in a very relax environment.  Good to bring your family as well.
author: Phillip M.

description: Cafe Sport used to be alot better when we first went there back in 1998, but since then it hasn't been the same.  The food is pricey & they don't serve you as much as before.  It's a nice place if you want something fun & crazy.  The atmosphere is interesting because there is so much to see as soon as you walk in.  The walls and ceiling are covered with much of the old italian memorabilia.
author: C T.

description: O.M.G. This place is incredible. Warning- you will be in a pasta coma afterwards. The best strategy is to go with a group, order family style and have a little bit of everything. The sauce is so flavorful and fresh. I don't normally even like pasta or order it that often. The decor inside is really colorful and fun, as well. I highly, highly recommend trying this place.
author: Hanan H.

description:
"Oh, who f#*king cares.  You'll eat here if it is convenient for you.  Bet you'd eat here if I took care of the bill and the Chianti kept refilling your butter-smudged glass.  This ship is going nowhere.  Look outside, dummy.  Everything is still everywhere.  The street is still outside.  Stop irritating the poor couple behind us.  They do not care that your lobster pasta is "f#*kin' awesome" and they really don't want me to take a picture of all three of you." 
- Sam Granat's offering on North Beach's Caffe Sport  (San Anselmo's favorite yelper!)  

After a long walk from The Mission to Pier 39 then up to North Beach (looking for a place that would accept my debit card), my date and I were really thirsty and hungry (and tired) and one of us was getting angrier by the moment.  I was kicked out of Golden Boy Pizza for throwing coins at the off-duty meter maid sitting at the counter with a veggie slice, grumbling at the blinking Hummer double-parked outside.  And the place next door to that wouldn't let me in because of a temporary inability to walk forward without first falling backwards.  Then... finally... 

"Caffe Sport: a narrow passageway with big everything - - -  wow  - - - and affordable prices." 
- Don McPherson (Vacaville's own)  

I couldn't say it better myself.

What can I say about the place, then?  It's a wild ride ... (I only remember being here because someone managed to snap a photo of me bracing the bench during gravity checks.)  The karaoke machine in my head was barking digits to my tongue in sectional codes.  My brain was laughing while my smile was trying to do all the talking.  My head editor was away and not taking any of these calls.  Luckily, it was a busier night here, out there. The white aprons were misplacing the kitchen appliances in their improper order - well, the whole staff of three had plenty of things on their minds.  And the patrons were more interested in talking about their netflix queues than about me and my date arguing about the Italians on the wall.  

No, everything was in control - in chaos...  The waiter impressed even the half-dead with fancy footwork from kitchen to table and back again.  Behind the scenes, the dishwasher was winning the war against pots and pans running into each other for no known reason.  The heavyweight forks on the table wouldn't stop sliding around until finally smothered by a cloth napkin.  Then, came the small guy with the big voice throwing down the noodles with a sloppy blanket of pesto sauce - and a dauntless grin.  I will always remember how that first bite made me forget about the dwindling flame in my brass wine bucket.  The garlic took hold and everything became heavenly like bread beckoning for oily green dipping.  My palate was charcoal by the end of the night, but the music was clear like the brush strokes of a skilled painter as the wine began opening up.  My belt was loosened and the table no longer threatened to suffocate me.  The narrow hallway they called a restaurant no longer made me fearful of never hearing your laughter again.  I had finally made it.
author: Kenny R.

description:
big enough portion for four people when you order an entree each person.  we had reservations for six and then it went to four.  this place just seemed like your average italian restaurant you would normally see in north beach.  Not as noted as the stinkin rose or steps of rome though.  the sauce on their pastas were pretty heavy and their pesto was too salty.  we skipped dessert here.  

not for bigger groups than 8 but i was hoping for some dishes i would normally get at italian like gnocchi or spaghetti.  I wished that they had "Cash Only" on the menu because when we got the bill and i pulled out my card to pay for the difference my friends paid.  Or at least a clear "Cash Only" sign somewhere when you walk in because i didn't see one.  

i dunno.  i would end up coming back here.  but not my #1 place to eat in North beach.
author: Daphne A.

description: Caffe Sport is my favorite Authentic Italian Family Style restaurant in San Francisco, period!   Eventhough they only accept cash and make you go across the street for the ATM machine.  The bread dipping sauce is unbelievable.  I don't even know what's in there and why they can't sell me a bucket of that stuff to go.  I'd love to recommend a dish or two, but really you can't go wrong with anything here.  Great staff and funky interior that is really Italian and San Francisco influenced.  So bring a couple friends, order about 4 dishes, and don't forget to bring cash!
author: Jason A.

description:
finally made it here (even though it's just around the corner from my place).  i would say it's the best italian in northbeach.  the vibe in this place is incredible.  this is where you come to celebrate something at.  this is what buca di beppo is TRYING to model atmosphere wise.  this is also a fun place for a casual date (not first date though).  very cool.

the clams with pasta and the squid with tomato and garlic are both incredible.  the bread with dipping sauce is also awesome.  since i haven't yet been floored by food in SF, this was the night that i was.  the squid was very tender, the tomato sauce very fresh.  the clams with pasta was just filled with taste and topped with melted fresh cheese.

i will definitely come back, this is an awesome spot.  though at first the prices seem steep, it's b/c the dishes are large and should be shared family style.  next time i'll be sure to grab a few friends to make a larger party and have a few drinks there as well.
author: Jason J.

description: I am in love. I can come here over and over again. I was totally in love with the decor, and even though this place seems to feel a bit crowded, I totally love the food, the size, the menu. I can come here over and over again. WHO WANTS TO GO TO CAFE SPORT THIS WEEKEND? CONTACT ME! hahaha)))
author: jamila u.

description:
It seems like I've been going here since the beginning of time. I know all the waiters: I know about Luciano's tomato garden: his penchant for gambling; his annual trip home to Italy; I've been hearing about Antonio's twins since they were babies; and I could go on and on....

Now to the food. Back in the dot com days, my boss held his Tuesday meetings at Hunan's and Fridays were always at the Sport.  Every FRIDAY, for months on end, and for all of you that have tried the Sport, you know how rich this food is. And beyond the Fridays, you could find me there for family birthdays and special occasions. So as much as I love the place, I've overdosed on their menu years ago. But that doesn't stop me from devouring the sauce that they bring with the bread... I don't know what it is, but it's like garlic crack! Other favorites include the mussels and the scampi (especially when they serve it with asparagus). But be warned... the main ingredient in each and every one of their dishes is garlic, and a good portion of their recipes call for cream. This place is not for the lactose intolerant, and you definitely should not be kissing anyone after wards, in fact, you will be sweating garlic for days on end.
author: Chum L.

description: this is the coolest place. I love the benches -- so beautiful. don't even get me started on the superb food ! the mussels & clams were garlicky and bursting with freshness . . . and I don't even like garlic, go figure. the pastas were creamy delicious. the wait staff was excellent, no slackers here. pray to the parking gods for help and come here for an unforgettable meal. visit the god called atm and bring tons of cash also -- Visa is not everywhere you want to be
author: Prima D.

description:
My wife said this place has *the* best pesto in the world, so when we visited San Francisco recently we made sure that we went to Caffe Sport for lunch.

My wife was right!

We ordered the penne with pesto as well as the seafood stew in white garlic sauce.  The pasta was cooked al dente and the pesto was DIVINE!  The seafood stew was delicious as well.  To complement our two dishes, the tomato dip for the bread had a nice little kick to it that helped balance all the flavors perfectly.

I loved it!
author: Tim B.

description: Mmm.. Amo questo luogo. Aglio. Gambero. Pasta. Pesto! Lei potrebbe uccidere un vampiro con un respiro sporco dopo mangiare un pasto qui. Non sedere nella cabina del Glover di Danny - ci odia. Mangiare il cannoli. Mangiarlo su. Ciao!
author: Katelin H.

description:
This is one of THOSE places.
You hear the name and you're like "?!" I don't even like to watch commercials about sports! Naaaw, we ain't a goin there.
You'd be wrong you headstrong assumer! (remember what happens when you assume?)
This place has been there forever because it is good. 
It is fresh. 
It has nothing to do with sports.
My first time here, we all ordered our own dishes, two of us got the shrimp. Big mistake. Actually, it was huge. 
Your "dishes" come out on a platter, a big platter. It's family styleee, so come with people you like (or at least that you trust their hygiene practices). 
The waiters are excellent, funny, great and perfect.
The food is much the same - although, not funny, but in a good way. the decor.
What can I say about that . . . There's not an inch of this place that isn't covered in something. It's a little cave-like and a little claustrophobic. A little torture for a great meal never hurt anyone! Think of it as a character builder. Mama says those are good for the personality. 
Good to start off your Friday night, out on the town Saturday or any time you want to pretend it's the weekend. Take a group, manga!
author: Katie W.

description: Delicous italian food.  My favorite is the pesto pasta.  And the mussels are huge!  I absolutely love the interior - talk about eye candy!  And the owner and waiters are a hoot.  Great experience, great food.
author: nicole h.

description: This place has been around forever, I hear.  It's an excellent place for a medium sized group to go.  In general, really impressive cuisine and a unique decor make this place much better than anything else I've had in North Beach.
author: Jordan K.

description: "2 people recommended this place---and i was disappointed...pasta was rather blah. Not even that cheap. A lot of pasta, not much taste...lame. Eclectic decor"
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
We tried Caffe Sport last night after many years of absence. While the interior remains the same, the dining experience and taste of the food do not compare to the original "Caffe Sport." On the plus side, the portions are still generous (large enough to share) and we found the prices to be very reasonable considering the prime location in North Beach. For example, a party of two could eat for about $30-40 out the door by sharing a mixed salad ($7) and a pasta such as Penne with Pesto ($15 +/-) plus an optional 1/2 liter of house Chianti ($8). This would be more than enough food for most people as the portions are generously oversized. 

On the flip side, the taste of the food doesn't match up to the old Caffe Sport. Apparently the original chef passed away (according to what I've read online) and the trade secrets lost along the way. Although the food tasted fresh, it lacked the "punch" that it used to have. The Pesto was OK, but not exceptional. It wasn't the vibrant green color, but more of a muted green and without the customary garlicky nutty punch (the Pesto at Amici's East Coast Pizzeria is superior, by comparison -- especially when requested with "extra garlic").

Gone also are the huge tiger prawns that Caffe Sport were renowned for -- although we did try the Scampi (Prawns) All'Antonio -- which was served in a creamy white garlic sauce. The portion was generous and included sauteed asparagus cooked al dente -- but the sauce wasn't the typical garlic-white wine sauce you might expect, but more of a soupy mixture of mayonnaise, garlic, and herbs. This dish is not reminiscent of true Italian cooking and would have been much better in a lighter garlic sauce without all the mayonaise and/or cream. 

We also tried the steamed clams, which were full of minced garlic in a nice white wine and lemon broth. This was a better tasting sauce and had we known, we would have asked for the prawns to be prepared in the same manner. 

Also missing from the "Caffe Sport" experience (and only those who've been here in the original days would relate) -- is the "rude" service with an Italian attitude. While the service was OK this time, there wasn't the same "personality" and flair of the old Caffe Sport. Part of what made Caffe Sport famous were the lively waiters who'd yell in Italian -- and even give customers a hard time (as part of the experience) -- which made it a unique place in the City. In the past, sometimes they would bring you something different than what you ordered or argue with you about your choice of entree -- and tell you, "take it or leave it." But that was part of the fun of Caffe Sport and what made it distinctive. Interestingly, we were also able to get a reservation for four at prime time on a Saturday night -- just a few hours before arriving spontaneously. In the past, reservation weren't even a possibility -- you had to arrive early -- and line up outside -- and even wait for 1-2 hours for a table.....that's how popular it was. The lack of line on a Saturday tells me that Caffe Sport has lost some of its following. That's not to say this place was empty -- it was full, in fact..and we still had to wait for 15 minutes for our table for 4. 

All in all, Caffe Sport today is a decent place....just that I miss the old Caffe Sport -- and this last visit just didn't live up to our earlier experiences in terms of food preparation and edgy service. Maybe we're just nostalgic for the good old days -- and this shouldn't take away from the overall good value that today's Caffe Sport offers....but for those of us who've experienced the old and the new, there's a clear difference now...so if it's been a while since you've been there, don't expect to recreate the same experience as before. 

Overall, Caffe Sport deserves 3 stars for an overall balance of decent food, generous portions, reasonable prices, and quirky atmosphere....but there are several places in the City that now offer tastier food prepared with more skill also at reasonable prices -- such as Lupa near Castro (see my other review) and Pazzia on 3rd, among others. We probably would not go out of our way to return to Caffe Sport anytime soon -- although it could be fun with a larger group where the atmosphere is conducive to eating lots of carbs...along with some inexepensive Chianti... Buon Appetito!
author: Greg L.

description: Went here a few years ago with my coworkers, and the food was great, except for the fact that they're cash only, and they were being uptight about us being a large group and it seemed they wanted to get us out of there as soon as they could. Went back a few months ago when my friend was in town, and at first they were providing us with great service, but then as rush hour-hit, they were hurrying us out, even though we weren't even done with our wine. They came back over and over again, at least three times, and one of those times, they even knocked the wine out of my hand because they were so in a hurry. There's no way I'm ever coming back. I've been to many places, but I've never been treated like that. If they needed the space so badly, they shouldn't have sat us down in the first place.
author: Octavio V.

description: I am a big fan of this place.  The first couple of times i was here, i was undecided on how i felt.  But eventually, the food, service, and ambiance just win you over.  The owner is quick with the wine.  The food, while not overly complex is pretty good (and very fast out of the kitchen).  Their dipping sauce for the bread never seems to make it around the table before it is gone....  One warning though...  if you are going to get the prawns in light garlic sauce, be prepared to be tasting it all night.  Not necessarily a bad thing, but when sharing a cab with strangers hours later, you might want to hold that burp in until you get to you destination.  I suppose the only complaints are that every table ends up being pretty cramped and it is cash only.  However, eventually those two things add to the charm of the place.
author: Robert R.

description: We went there on a Monday night. The place was rumored to be extremely busy, cramped and I heard the waiters were rude??? Thankfully none of the above was true. I walked, or was rolled out, filled with delicious pasta and stinking of garlic. I cant wait for round two. Although not entirely sure I have recovered from round one.
author: Nancy B.

description: This is my favorite Italian place in San Francisco. The menu is limited but what is on there is good. I love the salad, penne with meat sauce and the prawn dish with zuccuni. Yum! Beware, you better like garlic, as this place does not scrimp on garlic. The seating is a little uncomfortable on the hard benches, but it is worth it for the food. Oh and don't forget to get some Tiaramisu. The best I have had! All of our out of town guests love this place.
author: Brooke T.

description: Family style Italian dining.  Big huge plates of pasta with lots of yummy sauce.  I like coming here with 4-6 people cause it's easier to seat and you can usually order more dishes for variety.
author: Kit E.

description: Went here with my girlfriend. I absolutely LOVED the ambiance. The waiters were also so attentive and very courteous. Small menu, but that's actually a good thing. It means they actually pay attention and care about the food they are serving to people.  The restaurant is family style, so one dish can easily serve two people.
author: Philippe C.

description: Excellent Italian food. In fact one of my favorites in North Beach and that says a lot. Good for dates or groups (food is servered family style). It's small, so make a reservation on the weekend. Definitely order the pesto and the lobster. And the sauce and bread that comes before the meal is soooo good!! Don't ask what's in the sauce, just eat it, and you'll be happy you did.
author: Melissa C.

description: This could be the worst restaurant ever.  I went a while ago, and it was offensive.  I got this fritto misto of seafood.  Fucking sucked.  Mussels fried...in the shell.  Right?!  All the seafood was rubber..shitty rubber.  We got two entrees, and they both blew.  And I sent back the fritto misto after a  couple bites, and they charged me for it.  WTF?!  Bunch of assholes, too.  Worst meal I've ever had.
author: Alex T.

description: MMMMmmmm. Be sure to bring cash. No cards. Decor is the best! It's like a pirate ship on acid, or a big whale threw up all over the ceiling. The loud boisterous Italian guy, maybe the owner?, was our waiter, great table wine and brought the folks here to do the "touristy" deal. I don't like seafood, which is hysterical here, because they have one, maybe 2, non-seafood entrees. Hey, it's a seafood joint now. I've heard in the past that they didn't serve seafood, and someone asked the management why not, and after some boisterous Italian howling, they said, what the hell, and put some seafood dishes on the menu. Now - the ravioli with meat sauce was the best ravioli I've ever had since I don't eat anything with tentacles, so were were all satiated and pleased as pigs in sh**.
author: Braden B.

description: NOW we're talking ITALIANO!!  This place is by far my favorite authentic Italian place.  They have amazing dishes (family style) and the crab salad is to die for (I dream about it for at least a week or two after).  When I lived in AZ this was my first stop when visiting SF.  Bring a good amount of cash though, its cash only and if you're like me and order three dishes, wine and tiramisu it can be expensive.  LOVE IT!  Ciao Tony!
author: Joella A.

description:
mmm this place has delicious food!
garlicy italian seafood dishes.
their menu is not very big.  the restaurant isn't too big either.
staff is friendly
they take only cash so make sure you take a trip to the atm before you come in :)
author: charlotte s.

description: The food  comes hella fast. And when I say "fast" I mean real Mf'ing fast. So if your blood sugar gets low like mine and you start to get so edgy that you'd punch a candy striper in the face, don't trip partna cause your order will be out in about 1 min. Portions are large and served family style. Prepare to be delished x 2.
author: Joe G.

description: This is a great place to eat, especially if you have a large group or want to dine with your family. I think the food is best enjoyed in family style fashion. I recently had dinner there with my in-laws and family and it was good. I particularly enjoyed the calamari salad, mussels, pesto, and shrimp scampi. The tiramisu and the canoli were good as well. It's cash only so stop by one of the several ATM nearby.
author: Irene S.

description: What can I say so many people already think this place is amazing - well I am one of them. I have been coming here since I was 12 or 13 with family and friends and I have been happy with the food ever since. Sad to find out Owner died a little while ago. He was a fun guy who loved the people who ate their and treated them like kings. Yes it gets crowded and you might be sat with other people if you go on a date but that is part of the fun. Yes the place only accepts cash but there are plenty of ATM's in the area so no worries there.
author: David H.

description: I don't know what the 4 or 5 star reviews are all about. Their house salad was the best thing we had, the 3 pasta dishes were ok but I know I make better pasta at home. Save yourself the time and go to Trattoria Contadina up the hill, now that's Goooooood pasta!
author: Kristin L.

description: If you want your fat content for the whole month - this is your place. Every sauce is loaded with cream. Shrimp Scampi is disgusting - covered in a white cream sauce! Where in Italy do they serve that? However if you can find something without cream sauce it is actually pretty good. Service was good. Ambiance overdone. Never go back.
author: Jon T.

description: Yum, yum, yum, yummy! One of my favorite, most delicious, nicest/but casual ambiance places to dine in all of San Francisco, for authentic italian food.
author: Risa F.

description:
i have a hard time paying 18 bucks for a plate of pasta with tomato sauce -- and i ordered the cheapest thing on the menu. but the food was great and the portions large. 

the decor here is fun and quirky, the wooden booths comfy, the waiter has a great italian accent, the food came out (almost too) fast, and i love this neighborhood. 

but it was silent when we walked in (and my date and i needed all the external stimulus we could get), so i mentioned something to the staff. be careful what you ask for: we got cheesy american idol hits. yuck. 

oh, and beware: cash only!
author: jean w.

description: Great Italian food served family style (platters). The calamari and pasta dish was delicious.Just had the calamari insalata (salad). It was cold calamari served in a cold garlic/parmesan/olive oil(?) sauce that was outstanding. I took bits of the petrale sole and rolled it around in the garlic sauce. So garlicky that I reeked the next day.
author: Vena V.

description: Don't be misled by the name of the restaurant. Caffe Sport is a restaurant, not a sports bar. In fact, it is a cute little place, a true hidden gem in north beach. The place is tiny yet cozy, filled with decorations, memorabilias and thingamabobs hanging on walls, ceilings and displayed on shelves all around the restaurant. The menu is a short, one-page sheet of paper with less than 10 selections but (almost) everything on it is delicious(never tried the salad). Caffe Sport is perfect for groups but i can also see it as a secret spot for low keyed couples.
author: Kwan H.

description:
* I've only had take-out from this place so the comment is solely on the food.

Let me preface this review by saying that my husband who never, ever "craves" Italian was the one who actually suggested to get take-out from here (He had eaten here previously on the recommendation of an Italian friend and loved it). As someone with such a propensity for food-finickiness as him, I was a little baffled that he wanted to eat pasta - but then I tasted the food and understood why. It's absolutely delicious! 

Since so many people have already reviewed the entrees (it's a pretty limited menu) I'll focus on the tidbits not listed:  ** The bread's dipping sauce looks like greasy hell, but tastes like heaven! It's bursting with flavors and has a creamy spicy overtone. For the life of me, I can't figure out what is in it (neither can ex-chef hubby) but it was so good I almost wanted to drink it. Seriously, trust the other Yelpers on this one. ** The Rustica all'Atonio doesn't list it on the menu, but had small clams (little-neck maybe?) in addition to the shrimp and scallops. This was so tasty even a non-seafood lover like myself loved it. * *We think there were ever-so-small bits of carrot in the Con carne e funghi (bolognese) sauce which if true, attests to the culinary skill of Mr. La Tona. Tomato-based sauces often require a pinch of sugar to balance out the acidity, but then chefs run the risk of adding too much sugar making the sauce taste "fake." If sweet carrots were indeed used (how clever!), Caffe Sport gets kudos for it! * There was so much food that 2 pasta entrees + 1 salad (w/ bread + dipping sauce) lasted for 2 people to have dinner, lunch then next day, then dinner again. To top it off, I thought I would have gained 5 lbs. from eating all that cheese and oil (as I do whenever we eat Italian), but Caffe Sport must use some kind of magic because even after wolfing all of that down, I didn't gain a single ounce. Good quality and great tasting Italian can be found afterall....
author: Colleen L.

description:
We came here with a big group because a foodie friend had recommended it. I'm not sure why. This seemed more like a tourist trap along the lines of Olive Garden (food quality) or Buca de Beppo (decor).
All pasta (penne) had clearly come from one giant vat in the back. Every single dish was covered in cheese (we had two people in our group who had lactose issues so this was problematic--they wouldn't even try to adhere to our request to put it on the side).
The service was sub-par--we never had enough water, and our wine wasn't served until we were almost finished with dinner, it took a very long time just to get the bill and pay.
We had an out of town guest with us and I was really embarrassed at the quality of the food--most places in SF have to adhere to some level of food quality to say in business. This was sub-par, even for a mediocre restaurant.
Do yourself the favor and make your own Italian food at home (or Luca take out--much better, authentic Italian quality and cheaper than this place) or go to a really good Italian restaurant like Flour and Water or Beretta (honestly, they don't cost that much more).
author: J L.

description:
I can admit that they cook pretty good pasta.  Atmosphere is pretty cool with all tiny decorations from Italy(I guess), and I like the sign it says "Pesto is a great dish but only Antonio (used-to-be the main chef) can CREATE.  

Yep pasta dishes like theirs are not cheap usually - especially right in the middle of Little Italy.  I will go back there when I feel like spending a bit over 20 bucks for perfectly boiled al-dente pasta with selections of seafood.  Fresh basil and chunk of garlic too!
author: T T.

description: Take a cab as parking can be tough, but this place, oh man, THE BEST!!!!!
author: J B.

description:
my homegirl tina took me, this being her second visit.  as soon as she walked in, the owner of this family restaurant greeted her with the biggest smile and offered drinks at the bar as we waited for our table.  

throughout the entire course--from drinks, to the appetizing bread with (yes) that awesome dipping sauce, to our huge sharing of pasta with meat and mushrooms, to our tiramisu and mochas-- we were served like queens.  always tended to.  never forgotten.  

and i loved, loved, loved, hearing people greet one another (perhaps  friends of the family owners) in the middle of the restaurant, sharing conversation in italian.  it was lively, wonderful, warm, and homey.  the decor, a bit much, but it works.  a nice, fruitful getaway from the bustling streets of north beach. 

tip:
share the plate!  portions are huge, ranging from $15 - $20 +.  tina and i still had leftovers!  

definitely going back :)
author: melissa n.

description: Best Italian trattoria in North Beach.  It's very authentic, the staff is absolutely amazing, and the food...ahhh bellissimo!!  I actually like the food here better than Steps of Rome...although I love that place, too.  Go with a big group so you can sample as much of the menu as possible.  And don't forget the chianti!
author: Erin H.

description: I am a little bummed about reading the reviews before mine. Cafe Sport is my "go to" spot in North Beach. I wish I could pop in every day for the bread and dipping sauce alone YUM!  There is not one thing I did not enjoy at Cafe Sport. The shrimp with white garlic sauce is OMG AMAZING! The 4cheese pasta is delicious! For some reason I am asked by tourist where should I go to eat. Cafe Sport is always my first choice. You can dine in or take it to go. Just remember, its Cash only. The staff is awesome, They have been there forever. This was my fiance's parents favorite place to eat when they were our age and now its ours. I can't wait for my next Hearty Meal at Cafe Sport!!!
author: Miguel V.

description:
ok... so my friend Josh and I decided that we wanted to have a light salad and maybe a drink.  I met him after work and we walked up to North Beach.  We tried to go to Sardino's ??  You know, that totally traditional and awesome Italian restaurant in North Beach?  Anyhoo, it was packed full of yuppies and we couldn't even try to belly up to the bar, so we walked back down the street.  Disappointed cuz it smelled REALLY good in there.  Like old Italian wine breath, and I really do mean that in a good way.  We were in a lacksidasical mood and neither of us really cared to take the lead and make the next decision. 

We kinda paused in our walk because we couldn't decide.  Josh noticed a big fat lady on a tiny little patio outside the door and because she was so fat and the patio was so small, we looked inside the door.  Inside was a veritable cornucopia of colors, textures, noises, and men in white t-shirts bustling about.  I mean we are talking gingerbread palace.  Not a square inch of that place was anything close to bare wall.  It was all really weird and unidentifiable stylistically to me.  I should know because I work on a design show for HGTV, but I didn't.  There was also a table of screaming ladies.  We kinda poked our way in, not sure that this was the place we wanted to be.. and then a small grey haired Italian man ushered us into a table with 4 really humongous spoons on it.  We thought the table wasn't set... and felt a little flustered at being placed... but still went along.  Menu's arrived, along with some cutlery, but the spoons were never removed... making us feel like our table was maybe forgotten.. .like us.  We went back and forth over whether we should leave.  I didn't see any salad on the menu and the prices were a little higher than I wanted.  Josh said not to worry cuz he was paying cuz it was my birthday.  Then I saw at the very bottom of the simple menu of only fish and pasta options, a Salat Verte.  I imagined a sad little salad with a few beet stings and a carrot string, you know the type you get at tourist restaurants claiming to be the best, and tried to make Josh decide to leave again... but we stayed, he was annoyed that I wouldn't just make a decision.  I decided that the style of the restaurant was "Old Italian Hansel and Grettle crazy gingerbread house import all weird things from Italy extravaganza with screaming girls and old italian waiters."  The girls were actually quite funny.  We ordered: the salat verte, a double order cuz we were imagining the sad salad and the dover sole sauteed with lemon, garlic and butter.  I ordered a sprite, which came immediately, and Josh ordered an Italian import beer which took three requests to appear.  The four spoons remained on the table the whole time.

The salad came.  It was a HUGE plate, easily enough for four people, delivered with an "I told you so" from our Italian waiter.  To his credit, he did say that a single salad would be enough.  He also plunked one of the big spoons into the salad.  So we weren't forgotten.  It was BEAUTIFUL.  Large pieces of romain with green olives and just a smattering of red onion sliced thin.... but the dressing OH THE DRESSING... It was like a pesto ceasar and I swear to you I have never had anything this delicious in my whole life.  Garlicy, strong, creamy pesto.  I noticed a handwritten sign on one of the many carved posts in the room that said something like: Alfredo da chef make a da best pesto but only he can make it".... and he was right, who ever he was.   

Our waiter came back and actually actually asked us " you like-a-da-sauce?"  We could only nod, our mouths full of crispy lettuce and tangy olives... da sauce dripping off of our chins.

Then he delivered our Sole. Another spoon got plunked onto the dish. OH mY GOD AGAIN!  crisp little pieces of tiny asparagas covered the fish, fresh, a whole boneless side of the dover sole and yes, lots of butter and garlic and lemon.   We ate like old italians I'm sure.

As we came to near bursting point, I realized that we had never inquired as to the name of this restaurant... We asked the "like-a-da-sauce" waiter and he pointed to his T-shirt.  CAFFE SPORT? we both said out loud.  Are you kidding me?  I mean, how misleading can a name be?  No sport paraphanelia, and except for the screaming girls, no tourists for that matter, and did I mention the pesto salad dressing?  The restaurant should have been called Caffe King of Pesto...   So the waiter came to check on us one last time and Josh offered him his credit card.  Like-a-da-sauce grabbed a menu and politely showed Josh that they don't take cards... nice and old school, just the way it should be. There was an ATM nearby and at the end of our meal, the waiter finally removed the unused spoons, making us feel quite special indeed.
author: emily h.

description:
5 stars for the crab salad.  Unless you are deathly allergic to crab or garlic (or are vegetarian), you have to try this.  It is one of maybe 5 meat dishes that I crave now that I've become vegetarian.  Comes in a mouth-watering creamy garlic sauce.  Dip bread it in after, I just can't get enough of that sauce.

Minus one star for the fact that their pasta dishes aren't that great, but who needs pasta when you have a delicious jumbo crab salad.
author: Olivia T.

description:
Great history, great people work there, great family restaurant.  If you want to support some good people and feel like you're with family, head for Caffe Sport.

That said, the prices are high for some of the dishes given what you get.  Don't get me wrong, some things are very good, but it's time for the restaurant to look inward a little bit and think about how they could improve a few of their dishes or lower the prices a little for the ones that are just average.  Either of those moves would make me a fan again.
author: Jeff K.

description: Gross. Some of the worse Italian food I've ever had. I'd rather have Chef Boyardee cook me a meal.
author: John M.

description: parking sucks.  cramped quarters.... well that's all the complaints I got .  inside you got a nice clean but cramped environment, very hospitable and helpful staff and delicious food .  portions are served family style but I suppose you can pig out solo if desired.  can't wait to.go here again.
author: Aldouse H.

description:
Excellent food, great service, Italian beer (and for just $4), wonderful atmosphere (family-run, quaint), and reasonable prices.

I can't get enough of the Pasta Rustica Alla Antonio.  The tiramisu is fabulous too.

If you're eating alone, sit at the bar and have a chat with the bartender or owner or myriad of regulars who'll entertain you with stories of Sicily.
author: Debra H.

description: The Fella and I ate here last night for the first time.  Amazing!  The Fella described this place as one of the tiny handful of places he'd actually go out of his way to eat at in California.  We loved the place just as much for the people as for the amazing food.  The couple at the next table were engaged and planning their rehearsal dinner here, recommended dishes and chatted with us about how the restauraunt has been such a part of their courtship.  The owner sat down with us and told us how his buddy made the Zebibo (dessert wine).  We had the green salad and the meat and mushroom pasta, a cappuchino and a glass of dessert wine and all were great.  Special note about the tomatoes in the salad...  somehow it seems he's got his hands on real hothouse tomatoes, not the soggy, ripened in the truck kind you find everywhere else in these parts.
author: Kri B.

description: Been going here since I was a little girl and its still delicious.  The meat sauce, the pesto, and the scampi are my favorite.  The bread always seems day-old, but the sauces are so good that you wont mind too much.  Your pores will exude garlic for a couple days after dinner here.  The decor and the waiters are cheezy, but the food is good.
author: Mary S.

description: My favorite Italian restaurant in North Beach so far.  Dishes are served family style, and is damn good.  The wine selection is limited, and seating is cramped,  but the food is awesome.  The waiters are fun, and the place gets a little loud.  Bring a large group if you can, so that you can try a bunch of the dishes.  BTW:  The pesto is to die for.
author: Lucas M.

description: This place has been around forever and thankfully has remained exactly the same. The food is delicious and plentiful and served in large family style platters. There are chochkies hanging from the ceiling and walls and the waiters are gruff but sweet underneath. They won't even hear of giving you butter for your bread. Sometimes you can end up at communal tables. One time several years ago, a woman celebrating her birthday with some friends shared our table. The waiter, upon hearing it was her birthday, crawled across the table to give her a kiss. They have GREAT prawns and also a 4 cheese pasta from the heavens. They have 2 dinner seatings and you need reservations.
author: Barbara S.

description: A fun place to take out of town guests. The service isn't great, but the decor is fun. God forbid you try to use a credit card. CASH ONLY! The times I've been there (late) the staff burst into song, I am not joking. The first time it scared me and I thought about escaping, but I was with a group of people from work. The crab dish is amazing. Kids love this place! Stimulation overload! Great fun had by all.
author: Mitsi M.

description: What a hidden GEM in North Beach! Food was great. On a Sunday night at 8 p.m. we were one of three or four tables. I only take issue with static Spanish radio over the sound system near the end of our meal. I guess they wanted us to leave. I'm just happy they're open on Sunday nights now.
author: Andy R.

description: The yummiest meal. Fresh seafood, everything served family style.  Be warned - lots of garlic.  Parking around there is a pain.  Best time to go is Saturday lunch - their seafood or calimari fritti is the best.  They don't serve that for dinners.
author: Mei B.

description: This place has a special place in my heart, because it's one of the first restaurants I sampled after moving to North Beach.   Their portions are huge, the service is ridiculously warm, and prices are reasonable.  Not a ton of selection, and it can be a tad on the oily side, but it's a damn tasty comfort option on a chilly San Francisco night.  And good service in that neighborhood is nothing to take for granted!
author: nicole l.

description: This is a great place to load up on carbs before a long night of whatever you're into in North Beach.  I threw an office Christmas party here 3 years ago and brought a party bus of 80 Realtors, who proceeded to drink the place dry before they all stumbled over to Beach Blanket Babylon.  Their bread sucks but you'll eat it anyway because the cheese sauce served with it is the bomb.  (secret ingredients include jalapenos and sardines)  Other favorites are the eggplant parmesan, pesto pasta, and shrimp scampi, which is not scampi at all, but rather, poached shrimp and zuchinni smothered in a mayo-like emulsion that surprisingly contains no cream.
author: Kevin G.

description: Strange name. Love the artsy coffee house vibe inside with all the colorful artwork. But on to the food: The petrale sole is frikkin' decadent, fish with garlicky, buttery, olive oily goodness, almost melts in your mouth. The calamari salad is amazing. Flavorful, plentiful, and super tender. FYI, it's not a salad like with greens (which actually sounds nice, come to think of it), but just sliced calamari with seasoning and olive oil. Even the bread and the spicy dipping sauce is great. This time washed down with a dark Moretti. Mmmmm. And by the way, food is served family style here--so you can imagine how big the calamari salad was. Our reaction was WHOA that's a lot of squid.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Good food, great service, fantastic atmosphere.  What more could you ask for?   And to make things even better, the last time we went the owner's (or maybe a waiter's) grandmother was sitting right behind us!  I felt like I was in Italia!
author: Bee M.

description: This is by far my favorite restaurant EVER! The food is amazing and so is the service. It's like a hidden gem in the city. Just don't plan on going anywhere after because everything is covered in garlic. Oh and don't forget cash because that's all they take. Enjoy!
author: Liana R.

description: Decent prices, and mammoth portions warrant 3 stars for this place, as does the friendly service...*but* the wine list is mediocre, and the portions are too big!  The pesto I had here was super greasy and oily, and whilst that can be good when it is late and you are drunk, it was not good for just a regular dinner time feeding.  The decor is funky, the patrons quirky, and the owners funny...unfortunately the food is not very authentic nor yummy...oh well...still worth a stop in once a year with out of town guests...
author: Francis K.

description: Yes!! Great portions, great sauces, great overall food quality. And I love the decor! Feels almost like you are inside a fishing boat.....can't quite explain it, but I kind of remember netting coming down from the ceiling. Anyway, the pictures and colors in here are great. They are a family style restaurant so great for sharing and the prices are so cheap! Whatever dressing they put on their house salad is phenomenal! I tried to buy some, but apparently they don't sell it. :) I am going to go back here with my family when they are in town. I love this spot.
author: Jenn L.

description: excellent. almost 5 stars...a classic italian meal. the lunch specials are wonderful and reasonably priced.  the atmosphere is perfect. very authentic italian seaside taverna. yummmmmmmmmmmm
author: S. G.

description: Wow!  If the Stinking Rose wasn't one overloaded garlic restaurant in North Beach, now there are two.  Way too much garlic in everything.  Garlic is not suppose to be an appetizer nor a main entree, it masks everything you order from salad to seafood.  Plus the menu is extremely limited.  What a downer, :(.
author: Christopher R.

description:
caffe sport is a family oriented restaurant. 
ive been eating here for 6 years now, and i know the owner and his son and wife. 
the food is mouth watering! 
ive stayed at this restaurant for hours just enjoying the food and then enjoying the company of everyone there. 
its a very small place but that just makes us be closer together! and honestly, who wouldnt like that?
all of the food here is just amazing. makes me speechless. 
but if youve never been here. YOU SHOULD ATLEAST TRY IT! 
trust me.. its great.
author: JOY P.

description: A friend recommended Caffe Sport to us.  We went on a Saturday night, parking was a nightmare, an irate "person" almost jumped out of his car to pummel me as I looked for a place to park.  The tiny place was PACKED, the staff was friendly and squeezed us in (for those who have been there we sat at a table in the entry area) We had a great time & the food was FABULOUS. It was well worth the parking stress, and we will be sure to eat here again.
author: Rebecca C.

description: I've been looking for a go to spot in North Beach to take out of town friends, and i think I may have found it. I typically don't go out for Italian, but will definitely be back here soon.  All the food is served up family style, which I love, and the service was on point.  Our group of 3 started with the inexpensive house salad ($7), which was great. We ordered a liter of the house wine, which wasn't all that great, but what can you expect for less than $20. We shared the spinach raviolis and the sole, which were both cooked to perfection. The raviolis were large, and just enough for 3 people.  The sole was flaky, and served up with zucchini, and lots of olive oil.  Enough about the food, the decorations are a bit all over the place, literally and figuratively...all four walls and even the ceiling.  Apparently, the owner is an aspiring artist.  In closing, what I enjoyed most about Caffe Sport was the no pressure waitstaff.  Even as the restaurant filled up, our small party of three was never rushed. Stop by next time you're in NB looking for a family style dinner.  Bon appetit!
author: David M.

description: Cafe Sport is just like Bucca de Beppo, but it's not a chain restaurant and has much better food.  The portions are mammoth, so bring at least a party of four so you can split two dishes and wash them down with a couple bottles of wine.  Always a crowd pleaser.
author: matthew w.

description: If you have a problem with the "butt-brush factor" then this is not for you. It is pretty crammed and can be a visual over kill. But, if you are about good greasy italian food this place is all yours, no really!
author: Divya R.

description: This name is weird for an authentic Italian restaurant. I loved the food. Huge meals with generous portions of olive oil and cheese. Yummy pesto. And ah the  decor...quite unique!
author: Maya G.

description: I LOVE this place!  The bread and dip is fabulous!  All the pastas are yummy.  I wish they took credit cards though!  LOVEEEE IT
author: Lynn S.

description: I used to go here in the 8o's all the time,and make no mistake the food is still delicious.Real Eastern Sicilian Food,the kind I grew up with.Pasta Aragosta was just unreal.For $20 a steal.
author: Jack M.

description: I love pasta. . .its the one carb that I never feel guilty about consuming.  So we started with the house salad, and it was full of fresh garlic.  Ohhh. . . how awesome that was (made me think of Stinky Rose up the street).  We had the pesto, eggplant parmesan (gonna learn to make it, it was so good) , shrimp scampi, a bottle of chianti and the scallop/shrimp pasta.  It was the perfect amount for eight people when we did it family style and only cost us $20 each.  The rocking' thing about this joint, besides the decor, was that each dish was saturated with sauce.  I am a major sauce fan.  I always hate it when pasta places don't give you enough sauce.  They gave so much, that we needed 4 bread basket to clean our plates on all the leftover sauce.  I was pleasantly pleased, but still, the food was okay.  I think it needs more flavor, especially to the pasta dishes.  Whether its more fresh basil, garlic or white wine?  Hmm. . . but I still loved it and I would go back, but it was only really ok to be honest.  And service was okay too. . . .acceptable, but I liked this place for sure.
author: Janice F.

description:
this place is so wonderful

the ambience, the noise of happy people, the walls covered with color and unpretentious art, the food - delectable - the waiters, loud, t shirt clad with aprons, amazingly sweet and efficient - large tiled tables, or intimate two tops - an amazing experience that will leave you happily filled with a robust and delicious feeling, in a good mood and happy.  love the food, the people, the vibe - and very reasonably priced, 2 people can eat for around 30 bucs, maybe 40 - i had the cioppino - it was so fresh and delicious, i ususally shun squid, but ate it greedily and looked for more - my sister had clams and pasta (all penne by the way) with a sweet basil sauce that was so out of this world.  just sitting in here makes you feel youre in italy where friends and food mean more than a lexus and a cell phone. 5 eager stars
author: John G.

description: LOVE this place. the pesto is creamy and f*ing insane. the bolognese is soo rich and flavorful. the 4 cheese, shrimp & scallop (rustica) pasta is exactly how it sounds....amazing! i don't get why this place is always relatively unpacked compared to the rest of restaurants in north beach. the salad had the yummiest balsamic vinaigrette, that sauce they give you for the bread is really good (what's in that?) and the service is great!
author: N. M.

description: We love this place. The foods are great. It's a fun place to eat and chill with your friends or family. Very friendly environment, I always feel like I want to get myself drunk when I'm here, but not yet cuz I'm constantly eating since the plates are big and so good that I can't stop. The price are so affordable. The main important things is I always enjoyed myself there. Everyone should go check it out.
author: christy l.

description: I give Caffe Sport 5* because it has food that cannot be duplicated elsewhere. The pasta pesto and scampi ala' Antonio are to die for. I compare this restaurant to K-Paul in New Orleans and Legal Seafoods in Boston in terms of uniqueness. There are hundreds of Italian restaurants in SF but none come close to Caffe Sport. The only downside is they don't serve hard liquor and their wine selection is mediocre. But they do make a great cappucino, and it is a fun place especially for a large group. When my daughter and son-in-law come in from Deleware, Caffe Sport is the first restaurant they make a beeline for.  Once the waiters get to know you they treat you like family.  The waiters will steer you to the menu entrees that they are currently preparing and you are ensured of freshness.
author: Bob Z.

description: What a place!! The interior is fabulous. And the food was fantastic! Me and my friend ordered Rustica all' Antonio and Con Cozze. Both dishes was great. They also got Italian beer ;-)
author: Robert R.

description:
Gotta be one of my favorite places to go.

You have to get the crab salad! YUMMMY! They run out often so make sure that you order it ASAP.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
This is just the best Italian food in San Francisco. Antonio, Yogur, Luis and many others make your dining experience the best.

Try the crab salad, clams (they will run out so go early for these), and ravioli.
author: Paul L.

description: Try the four cheese with shrimp and scallops.
author: A O.

description: This place is awesome and they have the freshest seafood.  I dont go too incredibly often.  I usually go with my family... it seems pricy is why but you get the freshest ingredients, tastiest food and if you're lucky the owner, Tony, will come out and talk to you or compliment your hotself about your looks.  Very comfortable setting.
author: Diana T.

description: I don't understand why this place is all the rage. Of all the Italian places in the city, why would you dine here? Yes, the decor is cute, but who cares when the food isn't that great. We came here for my friends b-day dinner, ordered maybe 8 dishes for 8 people including salad. It was hard to tell, bc everything was ordered family style so I wasn't exactly sure what the "portion" sizes were. What did I like? Ummm.... the salad??? The pasta was not that awesome. If you dine here I would stick to the seafood. The clams in white wine and garlic sauce were pretty good and the cioppino was ok although not very authentic. Every other place I've had cioppino, it was served in more of a broth. This cioppino here was like a mound of shellfish lathered in tomato paste. Service was mediocre. Make sure you check your bill because we were charged for dishes we ordered that never actually arrived. This also happened to the table next to us. Seriously? Who forgets an entire dish? Plus one star for the free slice of b-day cake.
author: Lauren Y.

description: this place is great for family-style dinners... but the real reason i go is for the sauce that comes with the bread. i don't know what's in it, but i find it pretty addicting. :) mmmm the sauce! the atmosphere is great too - the art on the wall really spice up the place.. it can get crowded so make reservations if you're going on a busy night!
author: Lucy C.

description: Interesting decor. Very simple lunch place. Interesting dipping sauce for the bread. The food was ok, nothing to write home about. Portions are typical small California portions. Another disappointing North Beach Italian place.
author: mark s.

description: The best family style Italian Seafood in the city! The prawns and mussels in white wine garlic sauce can't be beat. Great place to go for groups to enjoy a casual delicious family style meal.
author: Josh M.

description: I absolutely loved this place.  You have to go for the food, though, as the surroundings are a bit lackluster - no frills here.  I had the lobster pasta dish and was practically scraping the plate to finish.  You'll love it!
author: Layla K.

description: I am 32Yrs old now and started going to Caffe Sport  when I was about 7yrs old. My father "Andy Romano-Romasanta" "The Jolly Green Giant " and my mother are great friends with Tony LaTona the owner. We always loved going there to eat when we would drive up from Santa Barbara CA.  Tony would always take us on tours of the kitchen and take us up into the attic where he was making a tiny  5 foot sail boat that he had built by hand,  he also made all the furniture and chairs etc. in his restaurant. He was always cooking in the kitchen and his waiters never spoke English just broken English mixed with Italian. So special to eat at Caffe Sport, always mixing it up with other people at the table. The food is nothing you have ever seen before. Just as if you were in Italy! The menu I remember was hand written by Tony and the platters of food piled high to the hilt. Tasty and filling. My fathers picture was up on the wall the last time I was there and that is special to me to cherish these memories. I cant wait to visit again but I am now up in Sequim Wa kinda far away but I hope to one day be there to bring my 2 children to experience the great memories that me and my sister Shawna did. Boy am I jealous of all of you that get to experience Caffe Sport and the great experience. MMMM good. See you soon Tony!! Oh my gosh after reading the comments I just see that Tony has passed away, oh my gosh I am so saddened. I just wanted to see him one more time and taste his magnificent food and I see that I will never get that chance again nor my children. I don't even know if my father knows that he has passed away either being I know he hasn't been to San Fran for a long time. God Bless you Tony and may the lord hold you in his hands for eternity. You fed the world a beautiful and delicious mouthful of Italian flavors and I will always have my memories. God Bless your family. I hope your cooking up a storm in the skies above us........till we meet again one day my friend!!!!
author: Briana R.

description: I've been wanting to try Caffe Sport since I moved to San Francisco last year. I've heard great reviews, so-so reviews, and semi-bad ones. Last night, wandering around North Beach, we decided to finally try it out. When we walked in we were the only people there. It was 7 p.m., which for North Beach is like the early bird special. We shrugged, settled into an uncomfortable booth, looked around at the quirky artistic display and started perusing our laminated, one-page menu. I was a little confused by the menu and didn't quite get that it was divided by red sauces and white sauces. (my boyfriend explained that to me after I ordered). We already knew it was supposed to be family style, but I don't eat meat and my compatriot really wanted meat. So I ordered the penne pasta with red sauce and clams and he ordered pasta with meat and mushrooms. We split a green salad, which probably one of the best I've ever had. At first I almost choked because the dressing was so garlicky, but I soon got used to it and began inhaling the finely dressed leaves (did I mention the salad has cheese? any salad is improved 100% with the addition of cheese). Our main courses came out like 7 minutes after we ordered which probably because we were the only ones there, but I was still impressed. My meal was unbelievably great. I don't think I've ever had such flavorful and garlicky pasta before. The clams were cooked perfectly, covered in a creamy red sauce and sprinkled with cheese. It was definitely one of the most intense meals of my life. I'm still breathing garlic and hoping my work buddies won't hide from me all day. I strongly recommend coming here with a lot of people so you can try a bunch of different dishes.
author: Sammy S.

description: Garlic, garlic, GARLIC!!!  This place is like garlic heaven....when I walked into this place, the great circular rack of garlic on the ceiling told me i was going to have a great meal or at least heart burn....but luckily it was a great meal!  Absolutely wonderful meal, and the restaurant has so much character both in decoration and staff.  I love the old worn tiled booths and tables to match along with the crazy array of things hanging from the ceiling. Its a rustic, warm and cozy kind of place, and the host/owner is definitely old school Italian. And all that adds to the wondeful LARGE plates they serve.  Try the clams vongole (warning:only for garlic lovers), the eggplant parm: melt in your mouth good, and if you really wanna splurge go for the lobster pasta. Oh yeah and dont forget the house salad  for starters and end off with an espresso and tiramisu...BAMMO a wonderful meal at Caffe Sport!
author: Maria B.

description: for you pasta n garlic lovers...this is the place to check out but make sure you bring cash as they don't accept credit cards...strange huh? well...while sitting there you sort of feel like you are in a mafia movie...but the food is definitely worth tasting....lots of great and creamy sauces...try their garlic pesto with anything...my favorite...the prawns (gamberi) with the pesto.....
author: Mee-stique K.

description:
you have got to be kidding me.

this place is hilarious.
do not come here if you want to have wonderful meal. 
come here if you can't manage a cab ride to the olive garden without the expectation of freshness.

oh antonio. you serve carlo rossi by the  liter carafe.

don't go here if you want to have a regular bowel movement. come here if you want indigestion and a possible "atkin's stuff-up". this shit will come up like the mushy eggplant you try to enjoy.

i give this place 5 stars from the outsider's perspective. 
i give this place five stars because the big-
rock-toting marina skanks to my right were talking about how they "will walk off the lack of non-whole-wheat tomorrow."

i give this place five stars because the owner's face is on the t-shirt the servers have to wear. and it's not pretty.

i give this place 5 stars because pasta takes less than 4 minutes to cook and seems to come out as mushy as the EGGPLANT.... that takes longer than the pasta to cook.  
 
help this tourist destination get better and help the tourists get food poisoning. 

go here.
it is DELICIOUS.
author: Lucca B.

description: i went here with a large group for a birthday party -- we had a table reserved, so we were seated right away.  the service was quick and efficient, considering there were 20 of us and we ordered a lot of food!  the food was tasty and came out quickly, and the decor was fun and lively.  however, they only take cash, so be sure to come prepared.
author: Caroline P.

description: if you want great italian food, go to caffe sport!  saturday night was my third visit this year and we had the pasta con carne e funghi, pasta con vongole and an alfredo pasta.  the alfredo pasta was not from their menu but they were able to accommodate us which was great.  both the pasta con carne e funghi (w/meat & mushrooms) and pasta con vongole (w/clams) were delicious and full of flavor.  and it was cheesy!  yummm!  the place is small but quaint and gets crowded quick so be sure to make a reservation, especially for larger parties.
author: Vic S.

description: Was taken here by a blind date when he was told I like seafood. Caffe Sport was impressive and lived up to it's Yelp name. The decor and smug attitude of the host (who happened to lose our reservation but was excused on account that he has probably been working there for 20 years) could be replaced but the food made up for it. The special spicy sauce and bread to wet the appetite kept us from getting too tipsy before our delicious seafood delights, it was hard to keep myself from licking the saucer it came in. I ordered the Sole and it was impossibly fresh and perfectly seasoned with my three favorites: garlic, butter, and lemon, it also hosted a gang of perfectly steamed and of course very fresh asparagus. The pasta tasted and felt comforting and warm with yummy gooey cheeses and light, fresh shellfish. A little loud inside on a weekend but it made me feel at home in a strange way, loud and warm is sometimes a good thing when it's cold and foggy outside.
author: nina B.

description: Had pesto pasta and a calamari with garlic white sauce--both very good and heavy on the garlic (oh yeah).   Would have expected a fresh, crusty italian bread, instead was offered white bread  with a red bell pepper dipping sauce.     I took off a star for the semi-stale white bread.     The decor is brimming with Italian memorabilia from floor to ceiling.  What a sight.  Great place to take out of town visitors.   Waitstaff is cheerful and friendly.
author: BarkingDO G.

description: Don't let the strange name fool you... this place can cook up some mean Italian food! I have been unlucky with North Beach, without finding an awesome Italian place in a supposedly Italian neighborhood. I have gotten to trust Yelp, and since The Helmand was strangely closed due to a rock slide, my friends and I checked this place out. Decor is VERY unique, with wall to wall knickknacks up the wazoo! Makes for some interesting conversation! The vibe was very boisterous with everyone seeming to share their big plates of heaps of seafood and pasta with gusto. A good sign! We were seated quickly, no wait on a Saturday night! It was cozy, yet not cramped. The wait staff was super friendly, and efficient. We got 3 dishes, a seafood pasta, an eggplant dish, and the seafood stew-type thing. I'm not good with remembering Italian names. We got tons of bread with some yummy dipping sauce. Then the dishes came very quickly. The pasta had amazing flavor. Creamy, yet not heavy. I wanted to lick the plate clean! The eggplant parmigiana was awesome! The seafood plate was super generous too! I wish we got the mussels, as we saw everyone else getting it. It was a HUGE plate of 'em for only $18! They really know how to cook seafood just right, not one piece was overcooked! Three dishes were perfect for 4 hungry people, and ended up being only $18 a person! We got a warm farewell pinch on the cheek from one of the older waiters, which was very cute! I'll definitely be back!
author: Joy C.

description: We went there for lunch and were happy with the food. The lunch menu price is quite reasonable and the food portion is big. The food is good and the deco is adorable. Went on a weekend and did not wait for too long. I will highly recommend the seafood pasta. It is delicious.
author: Aileen S.

description: we went to this place due to  rave review from a friend, who went there long time ago. We had two pasta dishes and steamed clam. To me this is really  ordinary Italian stuff, I wondered  what the rave is about. The waiters are very courteous and service prompt, but the food is really not worth finding parking for (we had to circle around and around, finally paid $5 for 1-hr parking). Will not go back.
author: lingren w.

description: the best real italian food with wonderful staff who know how to run a restaurant with history and great food to back them up. they have a total loyal clientele and too bad for the people who walked off the street and did not understand the family is coming and that is why it is so crowded. one of three all time personal favorites-one in new york and one in honolulu
author: susan w.

description: Nice place.  LOOOOTS of food.  The manager(owner?) was a really sweet little Italian guy who talked to me in Italian.  Fun decor.  Not pricey.  I like this place.
author: Kelly L.

description: My favorite Italian Restaurant in the whole Bay Area, the bread and dipping sauce they offer you before you meal is all I need to eat. Its always worth the drive and the hunt for parking. Pastas have a lot of taste to them, especially the meat and mushrooms. Shrimp al antonio is super rich and creamy, but delicious, also their fried calamari. Staff is also really friendly.
author: Paolo B.

description: All i can say is, if there was one thing i had to pick to eat for a whole year and only that, it would have to be bread with that dipping sauce, that stuff is sooo good. All the entrees are heavenly, the service is great, the guys their are funny, the decorations are very nice. TO-go, yes. The pasta is delicous. Need i say more this place is great.
author: Andrew P.

description: Bummer. I really used to love this place. The pesto was miraculous, and that garlic-anchovy dipping sauce for the bread was wonderful! Usually the waiters are pleasant and a lot of fun too.  Recently, I had a friend visiting in town for one night, so I thought I'd take him there. I have never ever been so embarrassed in my life. He ordered something that came with cheese, and he didn't realize it because it wasn't in the description. He has Crohn's disease and can't eat cheese. Period. After some debating, he very sheepishly asked if he could order something else. The only time I have seen waitstaff be more rude was at Emmy's (throwing food and yelling: not classy). This waiter harped and harped and harped on my friend about what a big deal it was to send something back and how angry the chef would be and how his night would be ruined because now the chef would be angry at him. We were the only ones in there, was the chef really too busy to scrape off sauce? The waiter came back 3+ times to tell us this what a commotion we had caused in the kitchen and the ensuing fallout. Who is the cook back there, Nicky Santoro? (I watched Casio last night)....My friend was almost positive his new dish probably had spit or something worse in it if they were really that enraged. I was so embarrassed, I felt like I ruined my friend's night. What a bunch of joiks! Their pesto really is the best I have ever had. Many I will have someone get take out for me or something. I'm switching my allegiance back to Rose Pistola.
author: Mary G.

description: What a hoot this place is! When we first walked in, we weren't sure if we were in the right place but it sure turned out to be! The decor is wacky, crazy and full of life. Not a dull space on any spare inch.  We were not sure if we were going to be able to find what we wanted as the menu is not that big but we decided to stay and give it a shot.  The four of us started with a salad that was EXCELLENT!  Just a plain green romaine salad with green olives and a sort of creamy Italian vinegrette dressing that was superb.  We got our entrees one at a time and in perfect timing that we could all share and eat at a leisurely pace.  Entrees: pasta with a creamy tomato sauce with shrimp and scallops (excellent); petrale sole with fresh veggies (sole was light and perfectly cooked, melting in your mouth while the veggies, asparagus and zuccini, were crisp and perfectly cooked); eggplant parmesan (lightly breaded, small pieces, baked in a tomato sauce.....awesome); and last, scampi (shrimps were large with a thick alfredo sauce on top and once again, those wonderful fresh crispy veggies). If I had to 'complain', which was really hard to do if you saw our empty plates and feeling of satisfaction at being well fed by a very unique spot in SF, it would be the alfredo sauce on the shrimp was a little strange. It wasn't what we thought scampi usually has, but it was different and we did just fine emptying the platter!  Get there early so you can have a table. As we walked out around 6 pm on a Saturday night, the place was packed!
author: P G.
